snippet: Although banned by the New York City Police Department, the chokehold can often be effective in subduing a person resisting arrest and has been tough to eliminate its use by officers.
abstract: Death of Eric Garner after being put into chokehold by New York City police officer has prompted outrage and set off new round of scrutiny of stubborn persistence of practice, banned by New York Police Dept more than two decades ago; maneuver has continued nationwide as well, with at least 500 local police departments still training officers on chokeholds.

byline.original: By BENJAMIN MUELLER and J. DAVID GOODMAN

lead_paragraph: Although banned by the New York City Police Department, the chokehold can often be effective in subduing a person resisting arrest and has been tough to eliminate its use by officers.

headline.main: Despite Bans, the Use of Chokeholds Persists
headline.print_headline: Despite Bans, the Use of Chokeholds Persists
